!paste: mYth[SeNtiX] , you can stop the users from being able to run ps
mYth[SeNtiX] , and then create your own ps that shows only processes for the current user
mYth[SeNtiX] , any process has the x (execute) permission for user, group, and other
mYth[SeNtiX] , if you do  chmod o-x /bin/ps,  that means that ps can only be run by the owner, and people in the owner's group
mYth[SeNtiX] , you can also do chmo g-x /bin/ps, and that takes it away from members of the group
mYth[SeNtiX] , so you can control what programs any user can run
